title: ASIA MARKETS: Asian Markets Gain Ahead Of U.S.-China Trade Talks
text:
By Marketwatch and Associated Press

Nikkei posts strong gain as mainland China markets reopen after weeklong holiday; HKEX drops $37 billion bid to buy LSE

Asian markets gained in early trading Tuesday amid hopes that progress can be made at U.S.-China trade talks later this week.

China confirmed that its top trade negotiator, Vice Premier Liu He, would lead its delegation (link)in Washington for high-level talks starting Thursday. China has reportedly taken some issues that the U.S. views as points of contention off the negotiating table (link), however.

President Donald Trump on Monday said there was a "good possibility" (link) of reaching a deal with China to end the yearlong tariff war, though he added he would not be satisfied with a partial deal.

Meanwhile, the U.S. blacklisted (link)a group of Chinese artificial-intelligence companies that it said was making technology that the Chinese government was using to repress its Muslim minority.

The U.S. on Monday also signed a limited trade deal (link)with Japan, giving U.S. farmers benefits they lost when Trump pulled the U.S. out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership in 2017.

Japan's Nikkei rose 1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index gained 1.1% as it reopened after a holiday Monday. Mainland China's markets reopened after a weeklong holiday, with the Shanghai Composite up 0.5% and the Shenzhen Composite up 0.8%. South Korea's Kospi gained 1% and benchmark indexes in Taiwan , Singapore and Indonesia advanced. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 rose 0.4%.

Shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (0388.HK) jumped after the company announced it was dropping its $37 billion bid (link)to buy the London Stock Exchange, after the two companies' boards were "unable to engage." The LSE had previously rejected HKEX's bid, which turned hostile.

Among individual stocks, Japan Steel Works (5631.TO) gained in Tokyo trading, along with Fast Retailing (9983.TO) and Toyota (7203.TO) . In Hong Kong, Volvo parent Geely Automobile (0175.HK) , PetroChina (601857.SH) and property developer Country Garden (2007.HK) rose. Samsung (005930.SE) gained in South Korea after warning of a sharp drop in quarterly operating profit (link), though it said its chip sales could start recovering after the new year. Mining giant Rio Tinto (RIO.LN) was up in Australia.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 07, 2019 23:10 ET (03:10 GMT)
